results.title: Amelia Rose Towers
results.creator_credit: Ashley Scarlett, Nicole Sorby, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: If, as a child, you were picked last for a team. And sought as your refuge a wish or a dream. If you ever felt lonely, peculiar or blue, then Amelia Rose Towers is a bit like you! True! Amelia Rose Towers ‘ whose initials spell ART ‘ faces off against an adversary whose initials spell MAN, after passing through surrealist chambers and screens offering images of a personal identity that can never be reconciled. A story of juggling variables of reality of self and other ; of space, time and perceptions; of the art of science and the science of art but it is also a story of hope, love and courage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Scarlett, Nicole Sorby, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: Amelia Rose Towers
results.creator_credit: Jackie Farkas, Nicole Sorby and AFTRS
results.brief_description: This multi-award winning Australian short film is distinctly theatrical with its background of rap and parade of surrealist images. The atmosphere is acute and claustrophobic, full of anxiety, fear and loathing. Amelia Rose Towers, whose initials spell ART, faces an adversary who spells MAN, and offers us fragmented glimpses of her own fragile identity.

results.title: Amelia and the angel
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell and Anthony G. Evans
results.brief_description: A surreal fairy tale about a little girl in search of a pair of angel’s wings. The story is set in a background of London scenes, South Kensington, Earl’s Court, the Albert Memorial and Rotten Row. In the course of her search she visits a junk shop down the road, a jumble stall and finally tracks down a perfect pair of wings in a crazy artist’s studio. An interesting contrast is provided between the high-quality location photography and the surreal intrusions by a collection of fairy-tale characters. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Ambush at Masai Mara and Leopard, a Darkness in the Grass
results.brief_description: Ambush at Masai Mara - The wildebeest are coming and the hunt is on! It is the time of plenty for the lions of the Musiara marsh. Nothing quite matches the awesome spectacle of the annual wildebeest migration as the vast herds brave the treacherous waters of the fast flowing Mara River and run the gauntlet of the marsh lions. “Leopard: a Darkness in the Grass” - Survival on the hot plains of Africa is a tightrope between life and death, even for the big cats. The leopard is a shy and elusive prowler and this intimate film follows the extraordinary and hazardous events in the daily life of one particular leopard and her cubs in Masai Mara. Narrated by David Attenborough. Rated: G

results.title: Amazon: The Flooded Forest
results.brief_description: The Amazonian rainforest, flooded by up to ten metres of water every year, is one of the world’s last wetland frontiers. A magical submerged world and the greatest river system on earth, these huge flood plains are home to many remarkable creatures. The animals featured in this two part production include the primitive freshwater Boho dolphin, the Arowhana fish, dubbed by locals “the water monkey” because of its ability to leap two metres from the water to catch insects, and the strangest-looking monkey in the world, the Ukari. Narrated by Anthony Hopkins.

results.title: Amazon to ice
results.brief_description: Explore the wonderous waterways of South America from the infamous Tierra del Fuego to the raging rapids of the Upper Amazon; an area studded with relics from the ancient Inca past. A truly breathtaking journey includes the Moreno Glacier, the face of the Iguazu Falls and a visit to the inhabitants of the Islands in Lake Titicaca.

results.title: Amazing platypus [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The playtpus is one of nature’s shy creatures. Only twice has a playtpus bred in captivity. Because they are found only in Australia, and will not breed in zoos, most people know very little about the playtpus. This exceptional film shows the playtpus on dry land, underwater and by means of a carefully sectioned burrow , we even follow him into his home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Shaw, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Amazing platypus
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Shaw, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The platypus is one of nature’s shy creatures. Only twice has a platypus bred in captivity. Because they are found only in Australia, and will not breed in zoos, most people know very little about the platypus. This exceptional film shows the platypus on dry land, underwater and, by means of carefully sectioned burrow, we even follow him into his home. This is a unique chance to see the mammal in its natural environment. Suitable for primary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Shaw, John Morris and Film Australia

results.title: Amazing Grace
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Mary Hoffman and narrated by Alfre Woodard. Grace is a dramatic, creative girl who loves stories, whether she hears them, reads them or makes them up. Possessed of a wonderful imagination and a love of make believe, she constantly adopts roles and identities: Joan of Arc, Spider Man, Trojan Horse, Hiawatha, Mowgli, Aladdin, Dick Whittington etc. When her teacher asks who wants to play Peter Pan in the class production, Grace is very keen but dispirited when two classmates tell her she’s not eligible because she’s a girl and she’s black. Inspired by her mother, grandmother -“you can be anything you want if you put your mind to it”- and a Trinidadian dancer, she spiritedly auditions, wins the part and shines as Peter Pan. Caroline Binch’s radiant watercolour illustrations, the understated simplicity of the script, colloquial dialogue and endearing characters enhance the central positive message of self-affirmation. Suitable for children ages 4-8.
